summary: Now that you know how enzymes work, it's time to learn about one of their most important uses. Topic 3.4 goes over the complex (and quite technical) process of photosynthesis. Feel free to watch the video and read the lesson multiple times to make sure you get the hang of this process.

vocab.definition: Organisms that produce their own food from inorganic substances in their environment
An organism that cannot produce its own food, instead taking nutrition from other sources of organic carbon, mainly matter from other organisms
The fluid-filled matrix inside a chloroplast that surrounds the thylakoid membranes, location of light-independent reactions
Membrane-bound compartments within chloroplasts (in plants and algae) and cyanobacteria, serving as the site for the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis
Green pigments found in cyanobacteria and in the chloroplasts of algae and plants, that allow them to absorb energy from light
Tiny pores, primarily found on the underside of plant leaves, that regulate gas exchange between the plant and the atmosphere
The process plants, algae, and some bacteria use to convert light energy, carbon dioxide, and water into chemical energy (glucose/sugars) and oxygen
1st stage of photosynthesis, occurring in the thylakoid membranes, where light energy is captured by pigments (chlorophyll) and converted into chemical energy (ATP and NADPH)
A large protein complex that initiates photosynthesis by capturing sunlight energy to split water molecules into oxygen, protons, and electrons
A series of protein complexes and molecules that transfer electrons, releasing energy used to create an electrochemical gradient that drives ATP synthesis
The combined force driving ions across a cell membrane, resulting from both a chemical gradient (difference in concentration) and an electrical gradient (difference in electrical charge)
A multi-subunit protein complex in the thylakoid membrane of plants, algae, and cyanobacteria that uses light energy to facilitate electron transfer, producing NADPH
A cofactor used to donate electrons for anabolic reactions, including the Calvin Cycle in photosynthesis. NADP+ is the form that accepts electrons, and NADPH donates them.
A molecular motor in cell membranes that creates ATP, the cell's main energy currency, by using a proton gradient across the membrane
The biological process of proton diffusion across a semipermeable membrane down an electrochemical gradient, with the energy from this movement used to synthesize ATP
2nd stage of photosynthesis where the energy from ATP and NADPH is used to convert carbon dioxide into organic compounds (glucose) in the stroma
The cycle where photosynthetic organisms use ATP and NADPH to convert carbon dioxide into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (G3P), a three-carbon sugar that serves as a precursor for glucose
Earth's most abundant enzyme, which play a critical role in carbon fixation (converting inorganic carbon into organic compounds) during the Calvin Cycle
A three-carbon sugar phosphate formed through the Calvin Cycle; the direct precursor for synthesizing glucose
A chemical reaction where electrons are transferred between substances, resulting in a change in their oxidation states, such as photosynthesis and cellular respiration

videos.title: Crash Course Biology | Photosynthesis: The Original Solar Power
